ratings.comment: Funny guy and good at explaining material
I still can't  forget that endless homework even after 3 months. But generally great professor.

Professor Sondak is a great professor, but the course itself is very challenging. This was especially true for me, as I am not an Engineering Major. Luckily I scraped by with a C, but I worked my butt off. The curve is also pretty tough--you needed a 95% to get an A. Overall though, he is very passionate about math, and one of the better professors

Professor Sondak is far-and-away the best math professor I've ever had at UW. His lectures are fascinating, he is a very engaging speaker, and he explains everything very clearly. The curve is tough, but if you go to lecture every day and keep up to date, you'll do fine. Absolutely absolutely take a class with Sondak!
One of the best math professors I have had. Explains material clearly and with noticeable enthusiasm. He genuinely cares about his students. If you have the option to take a class with him, do it.
Oh my lord, the worst prof ever, don't take him, so much homework and tricky tests. No compassion for students

Great professor; one of the best I've had at UW. He truly cares about his students and will do anything to help. Homework is weekly and just like problems done in lecture. Tests are fair for the most part, but the curve is wicked. Average for one exam was an 83 and the cutoff for an A was a 97...

the homework takes forever, and you have to learn to code which is a pain. He also doesn't finish examples in lecture sometimes. However his exams are fair, as long as you keep up, you should be fine.
Amazing professor... really is. However, his curve is absurd. 55% of the class gets a C or less. If you score average on a test, you get a C. Look it up. I hate this man.

He explains things really well, probably the most interesting professor I have ever met. Although the hardness of the exams increases exponentially (for my section), if you study for it then you will get an easy A.
David Sondak is passionate about teaching and cares that the students learn the material. His lectures are entertaining and he only tests on the lecture material. Would definitely recommend.

An ideal college math professor here at Madison. Totally unlike the majority of the pack who solely care about their research and are just too busy with that to actually give a sh*t about the students in their classes. Tests were very fair if you did all the homework and practice exam stuff. Very easy to talk to, great for engineering majors
He's very sweet! He makes a lot of mistakes when he teaches, but is a good sport when someone corrects him. I would definitely take a class of his again.

I loved the way he taught. He first explains the basic concept, then proceeds to provide numerous examples as to how to solve different equations/scenarios. I rarely needed to read the book (other than doing hw problems) because the lectures were clear as to how to solve the problems. Overall, he did an excellent job.

Nice guy, it was his first semester teaching and he did good job. Pretty funny, a bit dorky, but funny anyway. He expected prior Matlab knowledge, but was willing to offer outside sessions to teach it. Not sure how those were, never went. Good guy and I wouldn't hesitate to take another class with him.

First semester teaching, very funny and kept lectures interesting. I would give him 10/10 but a few homework assignments took a ridiculous amount of time and he required us to learn MATLAB, which didn't seem to help my understanding of the material at all but instead wasted my time. Still would recommend him.

He's kinda dorky but people don't give him enough credit. Really tries to push you to understand why we execute problems certain ways. His exams are super easy if you have a good background in calculus.

This was his first semester teaching, and he did a pretty good job at it. Explains concepts well and tries hard to keep us interested in the material and show how it's applicable to our future careers. He's the best math professor that I've had here.
